name: tactility
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
[ U ] the fact that something can be touched, or feels pleasant or interesting to touch: Unlike the internet, books have tactility and weight. Different fabrics added texture and tactility.
[ C usually singular or U ] the way that something feels to you when you touch it: The work has a tactility that is ambiguous, due to its patina. His stage designs attempt to animate the textures of the material world, its tactilities, colours, and flavours. The smooth table had the sensual tactility of silk.
[ U ] the quality or action of touching someone or something, especially of touching other people a lot: Tactility is intrinsic to childcare. Whether through her tactility or her human qualities, she connected with the public.
[ U ] the fact that something seems real, as if it can be touched or physically felt: The tactility of these early colour images is striking - they are so rich in tone and hue that it is as though they have been carefully hand-painted.
